job_title: Digital Intermediate Film Colorist in Toronto, ON
pros: really exciting work in the company

pros: Working on really interesting projects

review_title: Good opportunity to get foot in the door
pros: Great resume builder, good opportunity to learn from process-focused team, and perks include films/tickets
cons: Not the best work culture, cut-throat at times, terrible leadership/coaching

pros: Both streetcar stops are nearby.
cons:
*Hiring biases & lack of diversity*
Men occupy the majority of roles across all depts, except functions traditionally held by women, i.e. customer service.
Even for technical jobs, 90% of an interview deals with the subjective at the expense of relevant work experience. This way decision-makers get away without having to explain/ rationalize/ back up their decisions, & are largely hiring based on 'thoughts & feelings'.
Skilled front-line staff - especially women - admit to no longer applying for internal office jobs because they're consistently passed over in favour of those with less experience. It may be for the best, given...

*Pay deficits*
Office roles pay 2017 wages in 2021, as they literally bank on young candidates not knowing any differently and/or being unwilling to ask for competitive salaries. 
Despite being unionized, front-line staff are paid below that of similar businesses & other non-profit organizations. In fact, the union advises staff against negotiating for better pay.
There are Festival office jobs that pay less than the front-line jobs - evidence that TIFF doesn't even have insight into their own business units, much less the competitive landscape.
Staff would need to watch 1+ free movies daily to compensate for the wage deficit. With this in mind: Are free movies really a perk?

*Feedback is futile*
When feedback is brought to HR & upper mgmt, they act as though it's a personal indictment. If they put as much effort into fixing issues as they do in telling you off for voicing them, it would be quite the place to work. Instead, they dig in their heels, refusing to consider that the system is dysfunctional.
Despite the best intentions of staff who enjoy working there & want to do their best, efforts to improve the work environment are wasted. This results in demoralized & demotivated staff.

pros: Film industry intersecting with brands
cons: Length of time at the company often trumps experience, talent and know-how when it comes to promotions.

pros: Mostly great people. Many opportunities to watch movies.
cons: Employee turnover very high...constantly onboard new people.

pros: the people are very committed

review_title: Great for Festival Experience in a Vibrant Atmosphere
job_title: Festival FOH Staff in Toronto, ON
pros:
-Having TIFF on a resume always looks great, as they are a world-class festival
-BellLight Box staff for training are great, and training leaves one feeling decently prepared
-The festival staff are given a package of tickets to see various films, The pass also allows for free entry from the rush line (if called from rush)
-Work with a variety of people with a wide range of experience and passion in cinema and the arts
-Relative choice in location tor be FOH in, as well as shift (morning, afternoon, evening)
cons:
-This is temporary work, and it works best for those who are students/  transitioning with contract work, or are willing to book off via vacation hours with other work as you must work all 10 days of the festival
-Can be a high-stress, intense, chaotic atmosphere. Some locations are better than others, and some shift times are better than others, but if you have anxiety, have difficulty managing crowds/ being in crowds, or feel easily overwhelmed under pressure, I would not recommend working festival. Management does their best to be accommodating, but ultimately one needs to know if they can handle how crazy festival gets

review_title: Hard work pays off but it's rocky along the way
pros: Coworkers are fun, dynamic and dedicated; for the most part people are passionate about their work and really care about putting out a great product; highly rewarding when we pull off a great festival or event; free movies; fun staff events
cons:
Low pay relative to the hours worked and stress caused; too many cooks in the kitchen; unclear direction from management; high stress due to egos clashing and not always knowing who's leading a project; bad interdepartmental communication; people unwilling to step in and take ownership of a project and are constantly passing the buck, yet feel they can still call the shots; so much of your day is spent wondering why things simple things have to be made so complicated; leadership not always available for guidance and directors fight amongst themselves.

Would recommend to a friend if they were aware of the cons. It really can be a great place to work when things go well, but it's so high stress that it's not sustainable forever.

pros: Wonderful, passionate people; an exciting energy.
cons: I worked for TIFF as a seasonal employee for two festival seasons. In many ways it was wonderful, but one aspect will keep me from returning or recommending TIFF.  The person I reported to was an outright witch. She works near 24-7 under the guise of a dedicated manager, but it only demonstrates her lack of focus, ability to get things done, and poor delegation. She is abrasive and rude, and makes flip judgements and decisions on little information. She demonstrated unethical in her perspectives and decisions. She maintains a very tense working environment, often complicating situations, later laying blame on others. People not only walk on egg shells, but have a very limited employment experience under her leadership. I would never return as long as she is there.

review_title: Great Perks, High Turnover, Long Hours
pros: Free screenings, good benefits, fun community and work culture, discounted tickets to events and screenings, great at including all staff in meetings and celebrations, departments are interdependent allowing all staff to get to know one another.  Great internal website.
cons: High turnover, low pay, extremely long hours in preparation for festival, hiring practice is flawed.  There have been multiple times when interviews are done to satisfy the HR policies however offers have been made to the desired candidate before the job was even posted.  Leads to poor morale.  As of late, entire departments have been fired, many roles have been axed, questionable future despite their position as a fixture in the Canadian and film communities.

pros:
TIFF is a good company to work for overall. The people are passionate about film and have a strong sense of pride in the brand. 

HR policies are clear and well communicated. Good flexibility ie: flex time, WFH, lieu time post Festival.

Fun perks such as free films, access to industry screenings during Festival and discounts at restaurants and concessions at TIFF Bell Lightbox.
cons:
My department had a strong leader but not every department had strong or clear leadership. This lead to a lack of trust and lack of cohesiveness between departments. 

The organization does not seem to have a long term plan in place for their continued survival. Too much fire fighting - not enough planning. 

Very low salaries for those not in upper management. Salaries well below industry standards compared to other Toronto based, high profile non-profits.

review_title: There are worse minimum wage jobs
pros:
- very laid back co-workers and immediate managers
- clear outlining of what you're supposed to do
cons:
- upper management of the FOH department has an adversarial relationship with the staff - they fought tooth and nail to prevent us from unionizing to better our working conditions
 - other departments in the company held the FOH department workers in clear contempt a lot of the time
 - low wages, very little opportunity for advancement/promotion to other departments
 - constant competition for shifts, given the low wages

pros:
FREE FILMS

There a lot of different,  and interesting people who volunteer at TIFF, and the conversations can be good.

The staff (generally) really look after the volunteers and foster a sense of community among those working that shift.

Some shifts, there's a lot happening,  and it can be a lot of fun – though it was never so much that I felt stressed or overwhelmed.
cons:
Long periods of doing nothing.

Most shifts had a flurry of activity for about 20 mins as people were entering cinemas. Beyond that, mostly just wait around,  which is fine if you're outside with someone with whom you get along, and can have a good chat, or are an usher inside the cinema so you can watch the film. Other wise it's very boring.

I had one early morning shift where there were too many volunteers working. I basically did nothing for 7 hrs.

review_title: Generally Good, but DON'T disagree with Leadership, even if you're an EXPERT in your field
pros: Young, creative, passionate staff. Flexible schedules 9 months of the year (outside of festival).
cons: Egos abound on the Leadership team. "Innovation" means do more with less. Being dynamic is one thing, changing priorities @ breakneck speeds without proper resource allocation is another. Extremely unbalanced staff allocation (i.e. some departments are way bigger than they need to be, others extremely undersized).

pros:
Great coworkers who are active members of the film community. 
Sometimes flexible schedule. 
Interesting events and involvement opportunities.
Some good staff perks especially around Festival.
cons:
Festivals are unorganized, stressful and shifts lack management support. 
Many labour laws go out the window when things get busy. 
Long hours and hard work for little pay and little appreciation. 
upper management has no concept on how staff operate, however they are making all the decisions.

review_title: It's all about the people you work with.
pros: The staff are dedicated to providing the best service and most of them are great people who I like working with.
cons: Because compensation is not great, turnover is an issue and many people in different departments are doing the work of two or three people especially during the peak season...the summer.

pros:
Great sense of pride in contributing to a world class cultural event.
Fellow volunteers and TIFF staff are very helpful and friendly.
Free cinema vouchers.
Great work experience, especially for those interested in film, the arts, or anything involving working with the public.
cons: I honestly think there were very few cons.  A few members of the public were rude or snarky, but honestly only about 1% of them.

pros:
- you can watch a lot of films for free
- big, open concept office downtown
- co-workers were great
cons:
- overworked and underpaid
- complaints about management go unnoticed and mostly ignored
- hard work is not often rewarded; people rarely get promoted 
- favouritism is the only way you will move up

pros: Access to free screenings. Great for film buffs. Lot's of parties. Great organization for the support of film-making.
cons: Wishy washy, competency gaps in management. Unstable work environment. High turnover. Career development cap for professionals. It's a favourable environment for younger workers and students, experienced folks may become frustrated. Run away if you're a prof graphic designer.

review_title: High turnover, management doesn't care about lower level staff.
pros: Free movies. Like minded individuals. Discounts with reciprocal agreement. Health benefits.
cons: Lack of training. Often had to train my own supervisor. Lack of presence from management.

pros: Flexible working hours, awesome co-workers within nice building. Good benefits for employees and fun time during the festival and events.
cons:
Most employees are getting under-paid...
Having so many seasonal employees and it seems hard to manage and organize workspaces sometimes.

pros: There is always something new and exiting to do. I have the capability to express my freedom with almost no requirements.
cons: Very long hours. I do not have lots of time to be free during the summer as well as weekends.

pros: Great co-workers, engaging product and generally fun place to work.
cons: Disorganized senior management with little leadership.  At times overtime work with no compensation.  Poor pay.

cons: No cons, except for inconvenient waiting at some locations, but it is part of the experience
